text: Psalm 77
Remembering God’s Help for Israel
For the \add music\add* director, on Jeduthun.\f + \fr Ps 77 \ft One of David’s musicians (\xt 1 Chr 16:41 \ft ) \f*
Of Asaph. A psalm.\f + \fr Ps 77 \ft The Hebrew Bible counts the superscription as the first verse of the psalm; the English verse number is reduced by one \f*
I cry out with my voice to God;
with my voice to God, that he may hear me.
In the day I \add have\add* trouble, I seek\f + \fr 77:2 \ft Or “make supplication to” \f* the Lord.
At night my hand stretches out ⸤continually⸥;\f + \fr 77:2 \ft Literally “it does not grow weary” \f*
my soul refuses to be comforted.
I remember God and I groan loudly;
I meditate and my spirit grows faint.
You hold \add open\add* my eyelids.
I am troubled and cannot speak.
I think about \add the\add* days from long ago,
\add the\add* years of ancient times.
I remember my song in the night.
With my heart I meditate,
and my spirit searches \add to understand\add*.
Will the Lord reject \add us\add* forever,
and will he never be pleased \add with us\add* again?
Has his loyal love ceased forever?
Is \add his\add* promise\f + \fr 77:8 \ft Hebrew “word” \f* ended throughout generations?
Has God forgotten to have compassion?
Or has he closed off his mercies in anger? \qs Selah\qs*
So I said, “This pierces me—\f + \fr 77:10 \ft Or “this is my sickness” \f*
the right \add hand\add* of the Most High \add has\add* changed.”
I will remember the deeds of Yah.\f + \fr 77:11 \ft A shortened form of “Yahweh” \f*
Surely I will remember your wonders\f + \fr 77:11 \ft Hebrew “wonder” \f* from long ago.
I will also muse on all your work,
and meditate on your deeds.
O God, your way \add is\add* distinctive.\f + \fr 77:13 \ft Or “holy” or “set apart” \f*
Who \add is\add* a great god like \add our\add* God?
You \add are\add* the God who works wonders;\f + \fr 77:14 \ft Hebrew “wonder” \f*
you have made known your might among the peoples.
With \add your\add* arm you redeemed your people,
the children of Jacob and Joseph. \qs Selah\qs*
Waters saw you, O God;
waters saw you \add and\add* they trembled.
Surely \add the\add* deeps shook.
\add The\add* clouds poured out water.
\add The\add* skies ⸤thundered⸥.\f + \fr 77:17 \ft Literally “gave voice” \f*
Your arrows also ⸤flew about⸥.\f + \fr 77:17 \ft Literally “walked back and forth” \f*
The sound of your thunder \add was\add* in the whirlwind;\f + \fr 77:18 \ft Or “in \fq your chariot \ft wheel” \f*
lightnings lit \add the\add* world;
the earth shook and quaked.
Your way \add was\add* through the sea,
and your path\f + \fr 77:19 \ft According to the reading tradition (\fqa Qere \ft ) \f* through many waters.
Yet your footprints were not discerned.\f + \fr 77:19 \ft Hebrew “were not known” \f*
You led your people like a flock
by the hand of Moses and Aaron.
